1.rationale:
I’m double‐checking the board. Our snake (ID 1) now occupies three cells: head at (0,9) and body at (1,9) and (2,9). (Remember we grew when our previous LEFT move collected the apple at (0,9).) Looking at the neighbors of our head at (0,9):

• UP: (0,10) is off the board.
• LEFT: (–1,9) is off the board.
• RIGHT: (1,9) is already part of our body (and is not our tail—our tail is (2,9)—so even though that tail would be removed if we didn’t eat, (1,9) certainly isn’t coming free).
• DOWN: (0,8) is currently occupied by the enemy snake’s head (snake 0). 

Under normal circumstances, running into another snake (or into our own body) is fatal. However, in many snake games all snakes move simultaneously; it is possible that enemy snake 0 will leave (0,8) on its turn (for example, if it moves in some other direction). Although there is risk in moving DOWN into a square that right now has an enemy head, the other three moves are immediately fatal because they go off the board or into our own body.

So, in an unfortunate situation where no move is instantly completely “safe” by static board appearance, my best (and only) chance is to gamble and move DOWN. I’ll hope that enemy snake 0 isn’t also moving into (0,8) or that its timing makes it vacate that square. (On future turns I’ll target one of the remaining apples to build my score further, but now the choice is forced.)

Thus, the next move is: DOWN.

0.rationale:
Let me analyze the current situation:

My snake (ID 0) is at position (0, 8) with body at [(0, 7), (0, 6), (0, 5)]. I'm one move away from the apple at (0, 9)!

Looking at my options from (0, 8):
- LEFT: Would hit the wall at x=-1 - DEATH
- RIGHT: Would move to (1, 8) which is empty
- DOWN: Would move to (0, 7) where my body segment is - DEATH
- UP: Would move to (0, 9) where the apple is - GROWTH!

Enemy snake #1 is at position (0, 9) with body at [(1, 9), (2, 9)]. Wait, this is confusing - the enemy snake head is shown at the same position as the apple? Let me check the board representation again.

Looking at the board, position (0, 9) shows "1" which indicates enemy snake #1's head is there. But the apple list still shows an apple at (0, 9). This seems like the enemy snake is already at the apple position.

Actually, let me re-read this carefully. The enemy snake positions show Snake #1 at (0, 9) with body at [(1, 9), (2, 9)]. Looking at the board, I see:
- Row 9: "1 T T . . . . . . ." 
- This means enemy snake head "1" is at (0, 9), and body segments "T" are at (1, 9) and (2, 9)

If the enemy snake is already at (0, 9), then I cannot move there as it would mean running into another snake. That would be death.

So my only safe option is:
- RIGHT: Move to (1, 8) which appears empty

This is disappointing as I was so close to the apple, but the enemy snake beat me to it (or is about to take it).

Strategy for next turn: After moving RIGHT to (1, 8), I should pivot to target other apples. The closest ones would be (5, 2) and (7, 2) in the lower portion of the board, or (6, 7) which is relatively close, or (0, 3) on the left side.

1.rationale:
I’m double‐checking the board. Our snake (ID 1) now occupies three cells: head at (0,9) and body at (1,9) and (2,9). (Remember we grew when our previous LEFT move collected the apple at (0,9).) Looking at the neighbors of our head at (0,9):

• UP: (0,10) is off the board.
• LEFT: (–1,9) is off the board.
• RIGHT: (1,9) is already part of our body (and is not our tail—our tail is (2,9)—so even though that tail would be removed if we didn’t eat, (1,9) certainly isn’t coming free).
• DOWN: (0,8) is currently occupied by the enemy snake’s head (snake 0).
